stream_context.summary: Kaze brainstorms and designs NPCs for an oil rig-themed level, then undertakes a deep technical dive to implement a persistent footprint mechanic in a cement pit by rendering directly to a texture. He also collaborates with artist Biobak on the color palette of a separate temple level and discusses scrapping player skins in favor of a new in-game item economy.

development_findings.summary: The idea of cosmetic skins has been scrapped in favor of a new system where players can use coins to buy in-game items, potentially including house decorations or a 'safe power star' to bypass difficult challenges.

Kaze implemented a complex mechanic for leaving permanent footprints in cement by rendering them directly to a large texture, a solution chosen to avoid the performance issues of spawning many decals.
development_findings.quote: This is so much work for just a single stupid star.

development_findings.summary: To solve the complex problem of rotating footprint textures, Kaze opted to simplify the design by making the footprints circular, sacrificing realism for technical feasibility on the N64.

A brainstorming session for the 'Oily Boily Bay' level produced several NPC ideas, including Koopas in hard hats, Thwomps with protective vests, and a Wiggler overseer who gets angrier as the player causes mayhem.
Kaze is considering adding purchasable minigames to help players reach the total star count, citing Donkey Kong 64 as a positive influence despite the poor reputation of minigames in other ROM hacks.

Kaze identified a temple level's color palette as a major issue and worked with Biobak to change the gray bricks to a golden brown to better fit the aesthetic before any major geometry changes were made.
development_findings.quote: I looked at this level earlier and I thought holy shit this is so ugly... this is just color vomit.

development_findings.summary: A new health bar UI has been implemented which moves to the center of the screen when the player takes damage to increase awareness.

context_findings.summary: Kaze's design philosophy is heavily influenced by direct playtesting observation; he adjusts difficulty to reduce player frustration, as seen when he changed a death penalty to a 1 HP loss after watching Zeina struggle with a level.
context_findings.quote: My bar is usually when I watch the player and it's painful to watch them I need to make it easier.

context_findings.summary: Kaze holds a negative view of Twitch's current business strategy, believing the platform is sacrificing user experience for short-term monetary gain.
context_findings.quote: I think Twitch is going down. I think Twitch has made the decision to just squeeze out the last bit of money from the platform they can before it inevitably just burns down to the ground.

context_findings.summary: Kaze expresses strong disdain for the Mario 64 PC port and frustration with suggestions to use it, reinforcing his commitment to developing for original N64 hardware.
context_findings.quote: If I wanted my game to be PC only and have nicer graphics, I would just use Unreal Engine. And not like a shitty, garbage emulated PC version of Mario.

context_findings.summary: Kaze has strong, negative opinions on several classic Nintendo games, including Super Mario Bros. 2, 3, World, and especially Yoshi's Island DS, which he calls a "terrible" insult to the original.
Kaze mentions being paid for contract work on a 'A Hat in Time' project and another Mario fan project, indicating he balances his personal projects with professional commissions.

The professional and personal dynamic between Kaze and his spouse, Zeina, is visible; he relies on her for art assets and playtesting feedback, and they casually discuss their personal schedule on stream.

biobak.summary: Biobak provided real-time feedback on the new health bar's animation speed, suggesting it be made faster.
Collaborated with Kaze on the art direction for a temple level, testing new brick colors live on stream to fix a palette Kaze found 'ugly'.
Contributed a new water texture to the project via Discord.

zeina.summary: Her playtesting experience directly led to a core design change; Kaze reduced a penalty from death to 1 HP loss after observing her frustration.
Contributes art assets during the stream, being asked by Kaze to create tiny, pixel-art footprints and agreeing to create textures for ground pound and dive impacts.
Is mentioned to be working on other project assets in the background, specifically animating 'Bowser being a pouty boy'.

key_stories.title: The Persistent Cement Footprints
key_stories.summary: Kaze wanted Mario to leave permanent footprints in a cement pit, a feature with significant technical hurdles on the N64. After discarding other methods, he chose to render footprints directly onto the cement's texture. He simplified the problem by using circular prints instead of complex rotating ones, successfully creating a dynamic and persistent effect on original hardware.
key_stories.challenge: How to implement persistent footprints in a cement pit on the N64 without running into performance limits from spawning too many objects.
key_stories.process: Kaze first considered and rejected spawning decals due to performance limits. He then decided to render directly to a texture. He ran into issues with rotating the footprint image, which would be too complex, so he simplified the design to use circular prints. The rest of the process involved a deep dive into C code to handle texture manipulation, coordinate mapping, and debugging visual glitches.
key_stories.outcome: Kaze successfully implemented the feature by rendering circular footprints directly onto a large, static texture. This avoids performance issues and allows the entire area to be covered in footprints, though the initial idea of rotating realistic footprints was sacrificed for feasibility.
key_stories.key_quote: This might work. What is that Mario 64 level amazing? Is it for RTYI? Yes, it is. Okay. You're gonna be able to leave footprints in here.

key_stories.title: The Player Frustration Barometer
key_stories.summary: After watching his wife, Zeina, struggle and repeatedly have to restart during a playtest, Kaze articulated a core design principle: if it's 'painful' to watch someone play, the game is too hard. This led him to immediately change a death penalty into a minor health loss, demonstrating how direct user feedback shapes the game's difficulty.
key_stories.challenge: A specific section of the game involving falling into water was proving to be overly punishing for players, leading to frequent, frustrating restarts.
key_stories.process: During a playtesting session, Kaze observed his wife, Zeina, repeatedly failing at the same section. He identified her experience as 'painful to watch' and used this direct observation as the catalyst to re-evaluate and lower the difficulty of that specific penalty.
key_stories.outcome: Kaze changed the penalty for falling into the water from an instant death to the loss of a single health point, making the section less punishing and improving the overall player experience.
key_stories.key_quote: I watched Zayna play it and she would have had to restart the game 15 times. So my bar is usually when I watch the player and it's painful to watch them I need to make it easier.

key_stories.title: Fixing the 'Ugly' Temple
key_stories.summary: Kaze identified a temple level's color palette as 'ugly' and proactively collaborated with artist Biobak to fix it before further modeling work was done. They tested new colors in real-time on stream, shifting from gray to a more fitting golden-brown, showcasing their iterative and collaborative art direction process.
key_stories.challenge: Kaze felt a temple level was aesthetically displeasing, calling its color scheme 'color vomit' and finding the gray bricks out of place.
key_stories.process: Kaze brought up his concerns with the level's color palette to his artist, Biobak, during the stream. He explained that he wanted to fix the colors before Biobak invested time in remodeling. They experimented live, with Kaze changing the texture color in-engine to see the immediate impact of changing the gray bricks to brown.
key_stories.outcome: They agreed that changing the bricks to a golden-brown color was a significant improvement, making the level feel more like a 'Mario color' and fitting the 'El Dorado' inspiration. This decision was made before Biobak committed to a larger rework of the level's geometry.
key_stories.key_quote: I think colors just don't play well with each other... I kind of want to get the colors right like before you rework it too because otherwise you know we might have to like rework it again and again.
